node.title: Trump in the Spirit Over Trump in the Flesh
node.description: That was Glenn Youngkinâ€™s approach. Watch other Republicans mimic it.
node.content: ["What candidates don\u2019t do can have as much impact on an election as what they do, and Glenn Youngkin\u2019s victory in Virginia was a triumph of omission. It\u2019s no accident that he never beckoned Donald Trump to campaign with him. It\u2019s no fluke that he never appeared in public with Trump, the most popular figure in the Republican Party by far.", "But Youngkin, the first Republican to win a governor\u2019s race in Virginia since 2009, also never gave any particular sense that he had much of a problem with the former president\u2019s ethics (by which I mean the lack thereof), his lies or his efforts to undermine American democracy.", "He never denounced him. Never renounced him. Never provoked him.", "In no sane world and by no sound reading did Youngkin run without or away from Trump, though that\u2019s one of the spins being applied to his election in a state that President Biden won by roughly 10 percentage points just a year ago. Youngkin simply chose Trump in spirit over Trump in the flesh, a Trump Lite tack sure to be mimicked by Republican candidates in the 2022 midterms and beyond, at least until Trump\u2019s favor fades and his shadow shrinks.", "All of them are asking the question that Youngkin just answered: Can you have your Trump and eat it, too? Can you kiss up to his voters without visibly kissing his ring? Can you capture his magic without prostrating yourself before the sorcerer?", "Yes, you can \u2014 or so the Virginia outcome suggests. Political observers who say that Youngkin was a Never Trumper \u2014 proving the viability of that movement \u2014 are deluding themselves. He was a Stealth Trumper and Sorta Trumper who took pains not to offend or alienate Forever Trumpers. That was his central balancing act and one of the most fascinating aspects of his candidacy, because it distilled the prevailing Republican dilemma: to Trump or not to Trump?", "He split the difference, as did Jack Ciattarelli, a Republican who has defied New Jersey\u2019s liberal tilt to give Gov. Phil Murphy, a Democrat, the scare of his life. And Youngkin\u2019s victory and Ciattarelli\u2019s strong showing raise the possibility that the cultural and racial resentments of Trumpism without the thundering monomania of Trump may be a more profitable formula for the Republican Party than unalloyed and unabashed worship of its tempestuous god.", "That fealty cost Republicans in November 2020. But in November 2021? Trump is off Twitter. His rallies are fewer, so his railing is muted. His ejection from the White House translated into a partial exodus from the news, which he doesn\u2019t dominate as he did before. That gave Youngkin a kind of breathing room that Republican candidates last year didn\u2019t have.", "I promise you that Ron DeSantis took note of how Youngkin used it. I promise you that every Republican governor, senator and House member who is up for re-election next year in a purple state or district paid heed. The same goes for every Republican eyeing a presidential run in 2024 if Trump takes a pass on the race.", "They have been pondering the same challenge that Youngkin and Ciattarelli confronted. They are doing the same dance. They are testing the same proposition, which is that you needn\u2019t choose between Trump sycophancy and Trump apostasy. There\u2019s a halfway posture, a middle ground, and it can look to voters not like moral cowardice but like political prudence.", "\u201cYou don\u2019t have to denounce Trump,\u201d Russ Schriefer, a strategist who has advised the campaigns of Mitt Romney, Chris Christie and other Republican luminaries, told me. \u201cBut you do have to create your own identity.\u201d", "He noted that when Larry Elder, a Republican, failed in his recall bid against California\u2019s Democratic governor, Gavin Newsom, he failed to do that, \u201cwhich gave Democrats a bit of a false positive,\u201d making them think \u201cthat if we just say Trump, Trump, Trump, the Republican will start dropping like a stone.\u201d Youngkin\u2019s Democratic opponent, Terry McAuliffe, shouted Trump, Trump, Trump until he was hoarse, but, Schriefer said, \u201cthere was a very artful dance that Youngkin was successfully able to execute.\u201d", "That dance, though, hinged on a factor that got inadequate attention in the final weeks and days of his campaign: Trump allowed it. The former president was uncharacteristically even-tempered and restrained. Instead of taking offense at the distance that Youngkin kept from him, instead of taking the bait when journalists pointed that out, he professed to be unbothered. He claimed amity and mutual respect between the two of them.", "He saw that Youngkin had a chance to win, undoubtedly wanted to be associated with that victory and apparently understood the upside of giving Youngkin a pass on flamboyant Trump idolatry. For Republicans accustomed to needier behavior from the monarch of Mar-a-Loco, that was one of the most encouraging developments of all.", "Trump wasn\u2019t the only variable in play. He probably wasn\u2019t the main one, to the frustration of McAuliffe, who was as adamant about mentioning Trump as Youngkin wasn\u2019t. That\u2019s where the Trump-related lessons of Virginia have limits. The takeaway here is as much about Democrats \u2014 who, after all, have control of the White House and Congress \u2014 as it is about Republicans. Or, rather, it\u2019s about Republicans\u2019 ability to pin the constipation in Congress, the perpetuation of pandemic-related restrictions and a range of economic setbacks on Biden, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi. Being out of power has its perks, and chief among them is the ease of grousing versus governing.", "\u201cGas prices have gone up, there\u2019s inflation across the board, there are turkey shortages for Thanksgiving and predictions of delayed Christmas presents, and the Democrats\u2019 response is, \u2018Don\u2019t worry, we\u2019re close to banning methane,\u2019\u201d Corry Bliss, a prominent Republican strategist who lives in Virginia, said when I spoke with him on Tuesday. \u201cThere\u2019s a tremendous disconnect.\u201d", "Bliss\u2019s comments were a preview of Republicans\u2019 talking points for the midterms, and my conversation with him was just as telling in another way: Every time I brought Trump into the discussion, he ushered Trump out of it, but never with a hint of disrespect or scintilla of disdain.", "When I pressed him to analyze Youngkin\u2019s calculations vis-\u00e0-vis Trump, Bliss said: \u201cHe campaigned as someone who was proud to have supported President Trump and someone who was focused on solving the problems of everyday Virginians.\u201d", "Notice the pivot. It\u2019s in keeping with a dictum that Peggy Noonan, the conservative Wall Street Journal columnist, articulated recently: \u201cDon\u2019t insult Donald Trump but do everything to keep him away.\u201d", "Youngkin was Trumpier in the Republican primary in Virginia than in his general-election contest against McAuliffe, and that\u2019s a strategy that will also be emulated. But he was Trumpy to the end.", "Oh, sure, the suburban-dad duds and Main Street Republican demeanor amounted to an unflashy antonym to Trump\u2019s style. But the culture wars? The portrait of school classrooms as racial re-education camps, school curriculums as commandments that white Americans apologize for themselves, school bathrooms as danger zones? Youngkin and his supporters trafficked in all of that, and it was Trumpy to a T.", "Youngkin also declined to tangle with Trump and Trump\u2019s most ardent supporters about the Big Lie, a decision that I think will become the determinant of whether Trump blesses or messes with a given Republican candidate. Youngkin stalled for months early this year to acknowledge the legitimacy of Biden\u2019s election, said that \u201celection integrity\u201d was one of the issues most important to him and indulged conspiracy-minded voters\u2019 fantasies that courts might restore Trump to the Oval Office.", "There were echoes of that in Ciattarelli\u2019s approach. As Matt Friedman recently noted in Politico, \u201cCiattarelli\u2019s campaign was silent when asked by reporters if he believed Biden won the 2020 election well after it was clear that he had.\u201d Mustn\u2019t antagonize Trump or his fiercest supporters.", "Evading Trump\u2019s wrath and emulating parts of him without embracing the whole of him were fundamental goals of Youngkin\u2019s and Ciattarelli\u2019s campaigns and are the driving forces for many Republicans as they plot their political futures. The intensity of their desire to pacify Trump is perhaps best captured in comments that Mike Pence recently made about Jan. 6. That was the day when rioters called for him to be hanged for failing to invalidate Biden\u2019s election, but he told Sean Hannity that journalists were making far too much of it in an effort to \u201cdemean the character and intentions of 74 million Americans who believed we could be strong again.\u201d \u201cStrong again\u201d equals \u201cgreat again\u201d equals genuflection before Trump.", "Don\u2019t interpret Trump\u2019s absence from Republicans\u2019 campaigns with an absence from their calculations. Those campaigns are political palimpsests, the scrawl of Trump still discernible beneath the tidier writing that candidates have done over it. Don\u2019t overlook the homage to Trump in DeSantis\u2019s flamboyant us-versus-them, own-the-libs theatrics: offering cash bonuses to unvaccinated police officers who relocate to Florida from blue cities or states, challenging cruise lines\u2019 insistence that passengers be vaccinated. Trump has educated Republicans, and one of the lessons is to be more like him. It\u2019s just not necessarily wise to be seen handing the teacher an apple."]
